Event.name: Give_impression
Event.definition:
<def-root>In this class of perception words, a <fen>Phenomenon</fen>, typically expressed as External Argument, and its perceptual characteristics are given some description. This may be a <fen>Characterization</fen> describing purely perceptual properties, an <fen>Appraisal</fen> (i.e. positive or negative judgment) or an <fen>Inference</fen> about some non-perceptual property based on the <fen>Perceiver_passive</fen>'s perception. <ex></ex> <ex>There's a hamburger bar open, and <fex name="Phenomenon">it</fex> <t>smells</t> <fex name="Appraisal">real good</fex>.</ex>
<ex><fex name="Phenomenon">What we drank then</fex> <t>tasted</t> <fex name="Characterization">like sulphur and ox blood</fex>.</ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Phenomenon
Arg.definition: <def-root>The <fen>Phenomenon</fen> is typically the External Argument of the verbs in this frame.<ex><fex name="Phenomenon">The soup</fex> <t>tasted</t> very salty.</ex> </def-root>

Arg.name: Characterization
Arg.definition: <def-root><fen>Characterization</fen> is the subjective description (of the <fen>Perceiver_passive</fen> ) of the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.<ex>Kim's new furniture <t>looks</t> <fex name="Char">sort of bluish</fex>.</ex><ex>The violins <t>sounded</t> <fex name="Char">as if they were in pain</fex>.</ex><ex>The city <t>smelled</t> <fex name="Char">like rotting sewage</fex>.</ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Appraisal
Arg.definition: <def-root><fen>Appraisal</fen> is the positive or negative judgement given to the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.<ex>Kim's hair <t>feels</t> <fex name="Appraisal">nice</fex>.</ex><ex>That trumpet <t>sounds</t> <fex name="Appraisal">dreadful</fex>.</ex> </def-root>

Arg.name: Inference
Arg.definition: <def-root><fen>Inference</fen> expresses some property of the <fen>Phenomenon</fen> that is not a direct feature of the particular sensory modality (if any), but rather is based on perception within that modality.<ex>Pat <t>sounds</t> <fex name="Inference">devastated</fex> by the bad news.</ex> <fen>Inference</fen> may superficially look like <fen>Appraisal</fen>, as in: <ex>That idea <t>sounds</t> <fex name="Inference">dreadful</fex>.</ex> However, it is not the perception of the "sound" of the idea that is "dreadful", it is the idea itself that is inferred to be dreadful based on what was heard. <ex>It <t>looks</t> <fex name="Infer">like Johanna is going to the ball without me</fex>.</ex> Note the dummy-it as subject in this sense of "look" and that "appears that" could replace "looks like". Here, it is _inferrable_ that Johanna will go to the ball without the speaker.</def-root>

Arg.name: Perceiver_passive
Arg.definition: <def-root>The <fen>Perceiver_passive</fen> experiences some perception without necessarily intending to, but makes a judgment about the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>. The <fen>Perceiver_passive</fen> generally occurs in a PP Complement.<ex>The milk <t>smells</t> bad <fex name="Perceiver_passive">to me</fex>.</ex> </def-root>

Arg.name: Body_part
Arg.definition: <def-root><fen>Body_part</fen> expressions are not common in this frame, but may occur with the verb "feel" (the only verb in this frame that does not lexically encode the <fen>Body_part</fen> involved in perception) or occasionally (and redundantly) with other verbs.<ex>The fabric <t>felt</t> soft <fex name="Body_part">on my skin</fex>.</ex><ex>The music <t>sounded</t> beautiful <fex name="Body_part">to my ears</fex>.</ex> </def-root>

Arg.name: Location_of_protagonist
Arg.definition: <def-root><fen>Location_of_protagonist</fen> identifies the position of the <fen>Perceiver_passive</fen> during the act of perception. Typically it is expressed in a PP-from.<ex>The house <t>looks</t> deceptively small <fex name="Location_of_protagonist">from the outside</fex>.</ex> </def-root>

Arg.name: Path
Arg.definition: <def-root>This frame element, usually expressed in a PP, is used for all path-like expressions, except those indicating the <fen>Location_of_perceiver</fen> (see above), that describe how the <fen>Perceiver_passive</fen>'s attention is directed during the act of perception. <ex>His voice <t>sounded</t> muffled <fex name="Path">through the wall</fex>.</ex> </def-root>

Arg.name: State
Arg.definition: <def-root>This FE identifies expressions that predicate something of the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>, providing some information about its <fen>State</fen> while the <fen>Perceiver_passive</fen> experiences it.<ex>Pat <t>looks</t> great <fex name="State">dressed in red</fex>.</ex><ex>The meat <t>tastes</t> delicious <fex name="State">seasoned with garlic</fex>.</ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Ground
Arg.definition: <def-root><fen>Ground</fen> is the perceptual background against which the <fen>Phenomenon</fen> is experienced (or not experienced) by the <fen>Perceiver_passive</fen>.<ex>The painting <t>looks</t> great <fex name="Ground">against the new wallpaper</fex>.</ex> </def-root>

Arg.name: Degree
Arg.definition:
<def-root>The extent to which a <fen>Phenomenon</fen> gives the impression that a certain <fen>Characterization</fen> or <fen>Inference</fen> holds.
<ex>John <t>looks</t> like his father <fex name="Degree">a bit</fex>.</ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Circumstances
Arg.definition:
<def-root>The physical or abstract <fen>Circumstances</fen> that determine the appearance of the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
<ex>The people I work with <t>seem</t> to either hate their jobs, or like them, <fex name="cir">depending on my mood</fex>.</ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Frequency
Arg.definition: <def-root>How often the Phenomenon has the <fen>Appraisal</fen>, <fen>Characterization</fen>, or <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.</def-root>

lexUnit.name: appear.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: give an initial impression of

lexUnit.name: smell.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: have a strong or unpleasant odor

lexUnit.name: sound.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: convey a specified impression when heard.

lexUnit.name: stink.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: have a strong unpleasant smell
